data.name: HUD_PythonScripts_Tip_Caption
data.value: Python Scripts

data.name: HUD_PythonScripts_Tip_Description
data.value: This is the number of uncompiled Python scripts I found in script mod files in your Mods folder.

data.name: HUD_PythonScripts_Tip_CreatorsNote
data.value: Creator's Note: If The Sims 4 works at all with Python scripts, it does so by interpreting them. Maxis' SmartSim engine does not Just-in-Time compile Python scripts in script mod files. This means they will either underperform considerably or not work at all. If these are your script mod files, strongly consider compiling their scripts to byte code using Python 3.7 and omiting the scripts themselves from the script mod files to avoid confusion and unintended side effects.

data.name: HUD_ByteCodeFiles_Tip_ModsDisabled
data.value: Because Script Mods are disabled in your Game Options, these compiled Python byte code files will not be loaded and executed by The Sims 4.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Select_Guidance
data.value:
Let's start by selecting any file for your mod.

It doesn‚Äôt matter if it‚Äôs a package or a .ts4script file. If there's more than one file for your mod, you can just pick the most prominent one, the first one you made, the one that‚Äôs first alphabetically, or pick one at random. Doesn‚Äôt really matter ü§∑. You'll be able to specify any remaining files later in this process.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Hashing_Label
data.value: Hashing

data.name: ManifestEditor_Hashing_Heading_1
data.value: Some players like to alter packages for their own purposes. üì¶

data.name: ManifestEditor_Hashing_Heading_2
data.value: üîê We should talk about what you're comfortable with.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Hashing_Info
data.value: I identify your mod's files on players' computers by examining the contents of the files, *not* by trusting file names. This is because players can (and do) rename mod files to influence the game's mod load order. I need to know what things in your mod's files to consider in identifying your mod.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Hashing_Warning
data.value: The inclination to increase this setting because the thought of players altering your mods upsets you is valid; but please do consider that some players may have a good reason for this, such as using your mod in a language for which you do not provide a translation, and arbitrary strictness here will punish them when that may not be your intention.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Info_MissingScaffolding_Caption
data.value: So, a manifest but no scaffolding, eh?

data.name: ManifestEditor_Info_MissingScaffolding_Text
data.value: There are only a few reasons this might happen. In any case, you are seen. 1. *You are* the original creator of this mod and you don't back up your files (in which case, for shame). You're going to have to re-add all of your mod's components without the scaffolding, but I will clean-up intramod requirements for you automatically as you go. 2. You're a kind soul adopting an orphaned mod and the marmot smiles down upon you. If so, we do have [some potentially useful advice for you](https://plumbbuddy.app/community-services/adoption-guidance). 3. You're *one of those* players who knows just enough to be dangerous, you lied to me during Onboarding, and now you're about to *do something **really stupid***. [Enjoy breaking things](https://youtu.be/m_F8wSZT3QY), I guess. ü§∑

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Warning_BlankManifestSnippetTuningName
data.value: Your `{0}` mod file is a package with a **Manifest Snippet Tuning Resource Name** which you left either blank or just as white space. Since I have to have something substantive and unique there, if we continue I'm going to generate something for you. If you'd rather I didn't, you can go back to the **Components** step and fill it in for yourself.
data.comment: This text is in Markdown. {0} = Mod File

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Warning_BlankModName
data.value: *Your mod has no name!* You can go back to the **Details** step and type one in, and probably should because if you don't: * If a problem comes up and I need to discuss your mod with a player it will be awkward because I'll have to refer to file names when I could be using a more familiar name. * If your mod is ever referenced as a dependency and then a player doesn't have it, that conversation gets even more awkward because I have to discuss them getting it without telling them what it's called.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Warning_NoCreators
data.value: *You haven't specified any creators.* Look, I know stepping into the limelight can be a bit daunting... but you deserve recognition for what you've done! You can go back to the **Details** step and fill in your own name and the names of anyone who worked with you on this mod.

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Warning_BlankDownloadPageUrl
data.value: *Your mod does not have a valid download page URL!* You can go back to the **Details** step and type one in, and probably should because if you don't: * If a problem comes up and I need to discuss your mod with a player it will be awkward because I'll have no place to send them on the web if they need to download a fresh copy or an update. * If your mod is ever referenced as a dependency and then a player doesn't have it or needs to update it, that conversation gets even more awkward because... again... what do I say? Google it? Come on, don't do that to me... üòî

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Warning_BlankRequiredModName
data.value: *Your **{0}** required mod has no name!* You can go back to the **Requirements** step and type one in, and probably should because if you don't and a problem comes up and I need to discuss your mod's requirements with a player, it's gonna be very vague. *Did you notice how I just had to tell you which requirement has this problem **with a number?***
data.comment: This text is in Markdown. {0} = Requirement Ordinal (e.g. first, second, thirteenth, etc.)

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Warning_BlankRequiredModDownloadPageUrl
data.value: *Your **{0}** required mod doesn't have a valid download page URL!* You can go back to the **Requirements** step and type one in, and probably should because if you don't and a problem comes up and I need to discuss your mod's requirement with a player, it will be awkward because the only place to send them on the web to try to find a fresh copy of the requirement will be your mod's download page. Not the best user experience.
data.comment: This text is in Markdown. {0} = Required Mod Name

data.name: ManifestEditor_Confirm_Note_BlankPromoCode
data.value:
Your mod requires packs which some players may not have, but might purchase specifically to use with *your mod*, and yet, you have not given me an **EA Promo Code**. If you do have one, you really shouldn't be leaving money on the table like this, friend. Consider doing yourself a solid, heading back to the **Requirements** step, and filling in that code.
If you don't have one, but you're interested in getting a commission for all the packs your awesome mod is about to help EA sell, please allow me to [direct you to where that journey begins](https://creatornetwork.ea.com/).

data.name: ManifestComponentEditor_ComponentName_HelperText

It would probably be smart, however, to still include the full name of your mod, e.g. Vacuum Clean the Cats: Discover University Support.

data.name: ManifestComponentEditor_ManifestSnippetTuningResourceName_Label

data.name: ManifestComponentEditor_ManifestSnippetTuningResourceName_HelperText
data.value: This component of your mod is a package file, so its manifest will be will be a snippet tuning resource in your package. This is the name of that resource and it should be unique. I will generate the full instance for the snippet tuning resource on my own using the Sims 4 modding community standard implementation of the 64-bit Fowler‚ÄìNoll‚ÄìVo hash function with the highest-order bit set. You can change it if you are feeling brave, but make it unique.

data.name: ManifestComponentEditor_SubsumedHashes_Label
data.value: Subsumed Hashes

data.name: ManifestComponentEditor_SubsumedHashes_HelperText
data.value: These are the hashes of previous version of this mod file. The manifest keeps them so that if I'm checking to see if a player has your mod installed because another mod requires it, the other mod requiring an older version of your mod is not a problem. However, if you make breaking changes in this mod file you should probably clear these out so that it will be obvious that your newer version isn't going to work well with the other mod. Otherwise, it's best to leave this field alone and let me manage it for you.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_ModGuard_Description
data.value: Since anti-virus software doesn't check for malware which can be in mods, TwistedMexi created ModGuard. Sometimes, creators' accounts get hacked and dangerous mods are uploaded to sharing sites. Protect yourself with ModGuard.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_ModGuard_LearnMore

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_ErrorLogs_Description
data.value: When your game or a mod logs an error, I'll let you know and we'll figure out where to take the error to get it looked at. Just so you know, this will be a Discord server. So, if you're unfamiliar with Discord or not interested in using it, you may want to turn this off.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_ErrorLogging_Heading_2
data.value: Having at least one of these installed will provide us with better error logs to share with creators.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_MCCC_Label
data.value: Help you install Deaderpool's MC Command Center.

data.name: Common_LearnMore
data.value: Learn more

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_MCCC_Pros
data.value: MCCC's logging is far more comprehensive than the game's and most Support Venues will happily review it.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_MCCC_Cons
data.value: MCCC does alter your story progression by default (e.g. causing NPC Sims to marry, have children, move, etc.). If this would bother you, you can prevent MCCC from doing this, but that can be unwieldy for inexperienced players.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_BE_Label
data.value: Help you install TwistedMexi's Better Exceptions.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_BE_Pros
data.value: BE provides useful error logs without affecting game functions or story progression.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_ModHealth_Casual_BE_Cons
data.value: Since it is less widespread than MCCC, many Support Venues will prefer its error logs a little less than those of MCCC. BE also makes a new report per error and freezes the game's clock while collecting information for reports.

data.name: OnboardingDialog_Caution_SpookingMacs_Caption
data.value: I may be about to spook your Mac

data.name: OnboardingDialog_Caution_SpookingMacs_Text
data.value:
It's awesome that you're using me on your Mac! It does *a lot* to keep you safe and one of those things is to stop programs from randomly going into your Documents folder. Trouble is, that's where your mods are (or will be), so I pretty much need to do that.
I'm going to poke in there now. If macOS pauses me to ask you if it's cool, please tell it that it's okay for me to be in there.
*Note: You can cancel this, but reading from this area on your computer is basically the reason I exist so I won't be able to continue without doing it.*

data.name: ManifestEditor_Composing_Success_Text
data.value:
Your mod's files now contain all the information I would need to: * show players a complete catalog entry for it; * tell script mod creators about your mod when a player has it installed; and, most importantly, * help players with installation problems involving it.
##### Manifest Hashes Need to be Maintained *Please remember to come back here and have me update your mod's manifests if you change anything*. I promise it won't take long and you can even use the **UPDATE ALL THE MANIFESTS IN MODS IN A FOLDER** button on my first step to update manifests for multiple mods at once.
##### Help Players Keep Your Mods Up To Date As an additional service to mod users (and to yourself), you may wish to consider listing your mods on [ModHound](https://app.ts4modhound.com/). That will allow mod users to check if they have the current version of your mods quickly and easily, either on the website or in PlumbBuddy, and gives more ways for them to check that it's installed properly ‚Äî a win for everyone.

data.value: This Might Take a While ‚è±Ô∏è

data.name: Archivist_ReapplyEnhancements_Caution_Text
data.value: I will need to go through each of your save files for this chronicle to alter them with your current customizations (and restore the original thumbnail if you're removed a custom one). Depending on how many saves you still have in The Sims 4 for this chronicle, you may want to grab a magazine or pull up YouTube while I'm doing this.

data.name: Archivist_Restore_Caution_Text
data.value:
I will happily restore this snapshot for you, but you should know that *if I do*, The Sims 4 will regard it as the most recent save in this chronicle, even though *you and I both know* that it... really isn't. Things might get a little confusing in here as you continue to save after loading this restored snapshot, if you intend to keep "bouncing around".
On the *other hand*, consider **creating a branch**. If your goal is to make a "What If?" style spin-off of your Sims' reality at a certain point in time and you intend to play both of them (even if one just occasionally), it will help you if you branch into a new chronicle. I'll change some numbers in the restored save file to make The Sims 4 see it as a different game, which will allow me to keep tracking of your save progression through both versions of reality separate and orderly üßº. And, *on top of all that*, I'll actually end up using even *less* of your disk space with a separate chronicle for the other timeline, based on how my compression works.
Or, ya know, maybe your intent here is to go back in time to correct a mistake and you have no interest in playing with the snapshots taken after this one. In that case, it's fine to just click the orange OK to accept that you've sat through my lecture ü•± and to proceed with the restore.

data.name: Archivist_Restore_Caution_Caption
data.value: Are you sure you don't want to create a branch?

data.name: Archivist_Busy_Restoring
data.value: Reconstructing and Slotting Save Package

data.name: Archivist_ShowChronicleDatabase_Caution_Caption
data.value: Please Be Cautious ‚úã

data.name: Archivist_ShowChronicleDatabase_Caution_Text
data.value:
Chronicle databases contain everything that is needed to bring your saves, no matter how long they've been gone from your game, back from the Netherworld ü™¶. They are *memory*, üê∂ precious and üåª pure. I'll show you the one for this chronicle, but only if you *promise* me you'll treat it nicely.
(Basically don't move it, delete it, open it... you know... give it odd looks. Be polite and keep your hands to yourself!)

You sure you want me to go looking for it?

data.name: ModHoundClient_Snack_Error_PackageHardLimitExceeded
data.value: I have cancelled your Mod Hound report request, which was to include a whopping {0:n0} packages. Homes, that is just too much. Most of that just has to be CC anyway, right? You should know Mod Hound doesn't analyze CC, so excluding it would enable me to actually request reports. Let's the total we're sending to at or below {1:n0}, which is Mod Hound's current package limit.
data.comment: {0:n0} = The number of packages the user is trying to send to Mod Hound, {1:n0} = The number of packages Mod Hound will currently accept at maximum

data.value: Exclude CC

data.value: Load Sandbox

data.name: ModHoundClient_Snack_Warning_ExcessiveNumberOfPackages
data.value: Uhh, you're sending a somewhat large batch of {0:n0} packages to Mod Hound. You may want to consider excluding CC, since Mod Hound doesn't analyze CC anyway. If you can get the number packages you're sending to Mod Hound below {1:n0}, I'll stop getting on your case about this.
data.comment: {0:n0} = The number of packages the user is sending to Mod Hound, {1:n0} = The current warning threshold

data.name: SettingsDialog_ModHound_PackagesExclusionMode_HelperText
data.value: Mod Hound has limits of how many mod files it will analyze and it is not designed to analyze custom content package files (CAS clothing, hairstyles, Build & Buy objects, etc. as opposed to mod package files). How should I determine which package files in your Mods folder are custom content?

data.name: SettingsDialog_ModHound_PackagesExclusions_HelperText
data.value: If any of these exclusions match a package file, I will consider it a custom content package file and won't bother Mod Hound with it.

data.name: SettingsDialog_ModHound_PackagesExclusions_EUA
data.value: When testing the path of a package file, I will always begin by considering it in the format Mod Hound expects, which means using forward slashes (/) instead of backslashes (\), even when in Windows. The path will always be relative to the root of your Mods folder, without a leading forward slash.
